TEXT: The applicant is a NORP citizen born in DATE and residing in GPE , GPE . He is a businessman . He is represented by Mrs. PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , who was his defence counsel throughout the criminal proceedings outlined below .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
A.

On DATE the applicant was arrested by the ORG . Upon his arrest , ORG decision was communicated to him , which he acknowledged by signing the document . According to the decision , there was a strong suspicion that the applicant had participated in the murder of PERSON , an offence under PERSON . The applicant was committed to the prison of ORG .

On DATE , the ORG searched the applicant 's home and business LOC and seized cash belonging to him , in the amount of MONEY ( ORG ) , in pursuance of S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW . His complaint was to no avail .
On DATE ORG heard the applicant . On this occasion he was again informed that there was a strong suspicion that he had participated in the murder of PERSON , a businessman .

On DATE the ORG heard the applicant who denied the charge . ORG ordered his detention on remand , holding that there was a strong suspicion that on DATE the applicant and CARDINAL further suspects had murdered PERSON by means of multiple battery and shooting . This suspicion relied on , inter alia , witness evidence and preliminary forensic pathology expertise . ORG found that , in the light of the serious charge against him and in accordance with S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( a)-(b ) of LAW , there was a risk of the applicant 's absconding or of collusion , if he had been left at large .
On DATE the ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal against the detention order of CARDINAL DATE . ORG found that ORG had ordered the applicant 's detention on remand on proper grounds .

On DATE the ORG prolonged the detention on remand until DATE , at the latest . ORG observed that the applicant was suspected of murder . The ORG considered that , had the applicant been left at large , there was a serious risk that he would hide from the authorities , abscond or obstruct the proceedings by co - operating with his accomplices . The prolongation was ordered in accordance with S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL and S. CARDINAL/A § CARDINAL of LAW . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal .

On DATE the ORG Office heard the applicant . On this occasion he said that he was satisfied with the conditions of his detention . Still on DATE he was transferred to the prison of ORG . On DATE the competent ORG Office carried out a control of the prison LOC , on which occasion the applicant brought no complaint about the conditions of his detention .
On DATE the ORG repeatedly ordered the applicant to be barred from having any contact with his concubine , so as to secure the proper conduct of the investigations .

On DATE a single judge of the ORG prolonged the detention on remand until DATE , at the latest . ORG , referring to the state of the investigations , held that further acts of investigation of crucial importance should take place in the case and that , although the applicant denied the charge against him , a strong suspicion of his guilt prevailed . In its decision , ORG referred to S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( a)-(b ) , S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL and S. CARDINAL/A. § CARDINAL of LAW . On DATE a panel of ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal as well as his complaint about the lack of reasonable suspicion against him and about the alleged failure to inform him of the charges brought against him .
On DATE the ORG impounded , invoking S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW , the applicant 's seized money . His complaint in this respect was to no avail .

On DATE CARDINAL officers of ORG carried out a control of the local prison LOC , on which occasion the applicant requested that the time allowed for taking baths be extended . His request was admitted .
On DATE ORG of ORG presented the opinion of an expert serologist .

On DATE the ORG informed the applicant 's lawyer that the forensic experts ' opinions which had been completed by then were accessible for her to consult . Furthermore , ORG , in reply to the lawyer 's complaint of DATE about the prohibition of contacts between the applicant and his concubine , permitted that these contacts be resumed .

On DATE a single judge of the ORG prolonged the detention on remand until DATE , at the latest , finding that the results of the investigation - including witness testimonies , expertise from a mobile phone company and fire - arm tests carried out by ORG - had confirmed the strong suspicion against the applicant . The judge , referring to the relevant provisions of LAW , considered that the reasons , which had initially necessitated the applicant 's detention on remand , persisted . On DATE a panel of ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal , finding that the single judge 's reasoning was correct . In particular , ORG held that the risk of the applicant 's collusion was considerable in the light of an incident in DATE , when it had been established by the police that he had attempted to persuade CARDINAL of the co - accused to revoke a testimony .
On DATE the applicant was again committed to the prison of ORG . In DATE , the applicant unsuccessfully complained to ORG about the fact that he had to share his cell with a “ gipsy ” person .

On DATE ORG rejected the complaints of the applicant 's lawyer about the lawfulness of the investigation . Also on DATE ORG forwarded the submissions of the applicant 's lawyer , questioning the lawfulness of the investigation , to the Békés County Public Prosecutor 's Office .

On DATE the Attorney ORG informed the applicant 's lawyer that her complaint of CARDINAL August DATE - in which she had alleged that there had been no reasonable suspicion of the applicant 's guilt , that the authorities had failed to properly inform the applicant of the charges and that his detention on remand had lasted unreasonably long - had been forwarded to ORG for further action and that a hearing of the applicant in that respect had not been considered necessary .
On DATE ORG prolonged the detention on remand until DATE , at the latest . ORG , referring to the relevant legal provisions , stated that the reasons for detaining the applicant on remand persisted .
On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's request for release . On DATE the ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal .
On DATE the ORG Office heard the applicant . On this occasion he said that he was satisfied with the conditions of his detention .
On DATE the applicant was transferred to GPE , GPE .

On DATE the applicant 's lawyer wrote a letter to ORG at ORG . Whilst admitting that the general conditions of the applicant 's detention in GPE were good , the lawyer requested that the applicant be granted access to the shower facilities more often than once DATE . In its answer dated DATE the Head of the ORG explained that the relevant rules in force provided that inmates should have access to shower or bathing facilities at least once a week and no exceptional treatment could be granted to the applicant in this respect .

On DATE the ORG preferred a bill of indictment against the applicant , charging him with instigation to premeditated murder and , moreover , with abuse of fire - arms and of ammunition , an offence under PERSON of LAW . The indictment involved CARDINAL further defendants . ORG was relying on the results of the investigation , which involved , inter alia , the following items : findings of the inspection of the murder premises ; evidence given by CARDINAL witnesses ; forensic pathology , chemistry , toxicology , psychiatry , serology and dactylography expertise ; consultants ' opinions concerning physical evidence , documents , fire - arms and other weapons ; and TIME of confrontation .

On DATE the applicant 's lawyer requested the ORG to order the applicant 's release . On DATE ORG decided that the applicant 's detention on remand be prolonged until the first instance court decision would be taken . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal .
On DATE the applicant again requested the ORG to order his release .
On DATE the applicant was transferred to FAC .
On DATE the ORG ordered the applicant 's release .
On DATE , upon appeal by the Attorney ORG , ORG quashed this decision and ordered the applicant 's detention on remand from DATE .
On DATE the applicant was finally released .

After having held CARDINAL court sessions DATE and DATE , on DATE the ORG acquitted the applicant of the charge of instigation to murder and convicted the CARDINAL further defendants of premeditated murder . ORG established the facts relying upon , inter alia , statements made by the CARDINAL co - accused as well as upon testimonies made by CARDINAL witnesses and some twenty experts . Having examined the entirety of the evidence at its disposal , ORG held that the applicant had not been involved in the murder . At the same time , ORG convicted him of abuse of fire - arms and of ammunition and sentenced him to a fine of ORG CARDINAL . ORG declared that the fine in question was to be regarded settled , having regard to the applicant 's detention on remand DATE and DATE . ORG also ordered that the money , which had been seized from the applicant and had subsequently been impounded , be returned to him .

On DATE ORG , upon the applicant 's appeal , re - qualified his offence as abuse of ammunition only and reduced his sentence to a fine of ORG CARDINAL . As to the grounds of his acquittal of the charge of instigation to murder , ORG amended ORG ruling , holding that the applicant 's guilt had not been proven beyond doubt .
On DATE the applicant brought , under PERSON . CARDINAL - CARDINAL/A. of LAW , a claim for indemnification for his detention on remand . The claim is pending before the ORG .
B. Relevant domestic law
CARDINAL . Arrest and detention on remand
According to S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW , a defendant may be arrested if his or her detention on remand is warranted .
Detention on remand is governed by PERSON . CARDINAL and PERSON . DATE to CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure .
S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides as follows :
" Detention on remand of a person charged with a criminal offence can take place for crimes punishable with imprisonment , if
a. the person absconded , hid from the authorities , or , because of the severity of the crime or for other reasons there is a risk of his or her absconding ;
b. there is a serious risk that the person would obstruct or render more difficult or endanger the proceedings if released ;

c. the person committed a further crime , also punishable with imprisonment , during the proceedings , or there is a serious risk that he or she might complete the crime which he or she prepared or attempted to commit or that the person would commit another crime . "

According to S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL , detention on remand shall be ordered by a court . As regards the competence of the different levels of courts to decide on the prolongation of detention on remand , S. CARDINAL provides that detention on remand , when ordered prior to the indictment , may last until the decision of the court in the preliminary proceedings before trial , up to a maximum of DATE . Detention on remand can be prolonged once by ORG for DATE at the most . After DATE , detention on remand can be prolonged twice by a single judge of ORG , but it may not continue beyond DATE after the remand order . Thereafter , detention on remand can only be extended by ORG .

S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that the authorities must aim at keeping the length of detention on remand as short as possible . If the person charged with a criminal offence is detained on remand , the proceedings have priority . According to S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL , detention on remand must immediately be terminated , if its reasons are no longer valid or its period expires without an extension .

S. CARDINAL/A provides that the court orders detention on remand upon the request of the public prosecutor . The latter brings the suspect before the court and notifies the defence counsel . The court then holds a hearing , where the public prosecutor presents the relevant evidence . The suspect and the defence counsel may make oral statements . The hearing can take place in the absence of the defence counsel . The public prosecutor may make a motion to the court for the extension of the detention on remand DATE before the expiry of the deadline of a pending detention order . A suspect 's motion for release is sent to the court via the prosecutor . The court holds a hearing when there are new circumstances necessitating it ; otherwise it decides without a hearing .

S. CARDINAL/B § CARDINAL states that the general rules on appeals against court decisions apply to appeals against court decisions ordering coercive measures unless provided otherwise in DATE . According to paragraph CARDINAL , the public prosecutor , the suspect and the defence counsel may appeal against the decision of the court . If the defence counsel was not present at the hearing , he may appeal within DATE from the hearing . If the decision was taken in camera , there is a time - limit of DATE from the service of the decision concerned . Furthermore , S. CARDINAL/B § CARDINAL provides that the decision upon the appeal shall be taken , within DATE , by a single judge at ORG , if a ORG decision is concerned , and by a chamber of ORG , if a decision taken by a single judge of ORG is at issue .

According to S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL , if ORG has jurisdiction pursuant to S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL to decide on the prolongation of the detention on remand ordered prior to the indictment , the Prosecutor General applies for the prolongation . Paragraph CARDINAL provides that if the period of detention on remand , as fixed by ORG , has expired without an indictment having been filed , the Prosecutor General lodges a further application for the prolongation of the detention on remand .

At all stages of the proceedings , the accused is entitled to lodge any requests and comments , moreover , to request information from the authorities about his rights and obligations under criminal procedural law , and to ask questions from any person heard at a court session , in accordance with S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . Information of the reasons for arrest and of the charges

According to S. CARDINAL of LAW , if strong suspicion occurs that a person has committed an offence , the authority shall inform him or her of the substance thereof , referring to the relevant legal provisions . Minutes shall be taken of the communication of the strong suspicion to the defendant , subsequent to which he or she shall be heard ( within TIME if detained ) .
CARDINAL . Seizure and impounding of property

According to S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure , the authority can seize any item , which constitutes material evidence , which can be confiscated under the law , or the possession of which is unlawful . S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that the seizure must be terminated immediately if it is no longer necessary in the interest of the proceedings . Paragraph CARDINAL provides that the object which should otherwise be returned to the person charged with a criminal offence can be retained as security .

S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that , in criminal proceedings occasioned by an offence in the context of which a defendant 's property may eventually be confiscated , the authority shall have the right to decide to impound the defendant 's property or part of it .
CARDINAL . Law - Decree no . DATE

S. CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( d ) of LAW no . DATE on the Enforcement of Punishments and Measures , as in force at the material time , provides that a person in detention on remand is entitled to correspond with his relatives and - upon approval by the public prosecutor or , after the bill of indictment has been preferred , by the trial court - with other persons and , moreover , to receive a visitor and to receive a parcel at least once DATE .

According to paragraph CARDINAL , these rights - save the detainee 's right to maintain contacts with his defence counsel - may be restricted [ by the public prosecutor or by the trial court , whichever appropriate ] in order to secure the proper conduct of the proceedings .
CARDINAL . Indemnification for detention on remand

According to ORG . CARDINAL - CARDINAL/A. of LAW , a defendant who has been acquitted by the court shall be entitled to indemnification for his or her detention on remand . Such indemnification is payable by the ORG . The means and amount of such indemnification shall be determined according to LAW rules on extra - contractual damages .
CARDINAL . Official liability action

According to S. CARDINAL § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW , official liability [ of the ORG administration ] may be established only if the relevant ordinary remedies have been exhausted or have not been fit to prevent damages . Unless otherwise regulated , this applies , as appropriate , to the liability for damages caused by courts or prosecution authorities .
